Context:
The Human Resources Professional Association of Ontario (HRPA) offers professional designations in HR. George Brown College's Centre for Business programs are accredited by the Accreditation Council for Business Schools and Programs (ACBSP), with 14 diplomas, advanced diplomas, and degree programs accredited globally in various fields like Accounting & Finance, HR, Management, and Marketing. The Centre for Business also provides field education opportunities.

Graduates of the Business Administration – Human Resources program can enter various positions in public and private sector organizations, such as financial institutions, retail, manufacturing, government, legal firms, human resources consulting firms, and hold roles like human resources coordinator, assistant, specialist, administrator, or recruitment coordinator. For those students wishing to pursue a Training and Development stream, they may apply courses towards the Certified Training and Development Professional (CTDP) designation offered through The Institute for Performance and Learning. Students with an overall grade point average of 3.0 or higher in the three-year Business Administration – Human Resources advanced diploma are eligible for block transfer admission into semester 5 of the Human Resources Strategy and Technology degree program at Seneca College.

Contact HRPA for information about obtaining professional designations: [HRPA](mailto:hrpa@ontario.ca)

Programs offered with work experience: B144 (without Work Experience), B154 (with Work Experience).

Field Education and career opportunities available at the Centre for Business.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Business Administration – Human Resources Program B144 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The Human Resources Strategy and Technology degree program is offered at Seneca College. Students in this program are required to complete 36 courses to graduate. Of these 36 courses, 29 are mandatory, 4 are Business electives, and 3 are General Education electives. Some students may be required to take COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) and MATH 1027 (Business Math with Remediation) before progressing to certain courses, but these do not count toward the 36 courses required for graduation and will result in additional charges. Students must complete at least three General Education courses chosen from Social Sciences (GSSC), Arts and Humanities (GHUM), or Science and Technology (GSCI). Students are responsible for making up any failed or dropped courses before graduation, which can be done during the day or through Continuing Education. The following is a list of required courses for the first two semesters:

Semester 1:
- BUS 1038: Business Concepts I (none)
- COMM 2000: Communicating Across Contexts (none)
- COMP 1010: Business Computer Applications (none)
- HRM 1029: Principles of Human Resource Management I (none)
- MARK 1020: Principles of Marketing I (none)
- MATH 1008: Math for Business & Management I (none)

Semester 2:
- ACCT 1036: Principles of Accounting (none)
- BUS 1040: Project Management (none)

Context:
The text provides information about the courses offered in different semesters for a Human Resources degree program at the college. Here's an extract of factual information from the text:

* Semester 1:
  * COURSES: Principles of Accounting (ACCT 1036), Project Management (BUS 1040), Professional Communications I (COMM 1034), Math for Business & Management II (MATH 1095), Human Resources Info Systems (HRM 1029 & COMP 1010), Principal of Human Resource Management II (HRM 1030).
  * PRE-REQUISITE: Managerial Accounting (ACCT 2031) for ACCT 1036, Human Resources Management II (HRM 1030) for HRM 1029 & COMP 1010, and Principal of Human Resource Management I (HRM 1030) for HRM 1030.
* Semester 3: CODE: N/A, COURSES: N/A, PRE-REQUISITE: N/A
* Semester 4: CODE: N/A, COURSES: Introduction to Economics (ECON 1034), Compensation (HRM 2021), Workplace Health & Safety (HSAF 1001), Employment and Human Rights Law (LAW 1006), Career Planning & Development (STS 1037), Select One General Education Elective.
* Semester 5: CODE: N/A, COURSES: Coaching for Effective Performance Management (HRM 2027), Labor Relations (HRM 2023), People Analytics (HRM 1030), Select Two Business Electives, Select One General Education Elective.
* Semester 6: CODE: N/A, COURSES: Human Resources Planning (HRM 2005), Training Design & Delivery (HRM 2028), International Human Resources Management (HRM 3005), Select Two Business Electives, Select One General Education Elective.
* Recommended business electives: Microeconomics and/or Macroeconomics.
* HRPA-approved courses: The text mentions that the applicable HR courses have been approved by The Human Resources Professional Association of Ontario (HRPA).

Please note that this extract only contains factual information, and does not include any interpretations or opinions.

Context:
Extracted Information:

The Association of Ontario (HRPA) offers HRPA designations for students who complete the following streams: Training & Development Stream and Payroll Practitioner Stream.

**Training & Development Stream:**
Upon completing the courses below, students can pursue the Certified Training and Development Professional Designation (CTDP):
- HRM 2002: Training & Development
- HRM 1030: N/A
- HRM 2028: Training Design & Delivery
- HRM 2002
- HRM 2027: Coaching for Effective Performance Management
- HRM 1029: N/A

**Payroll Practitioner Stream:**
Students interested in Payroll Administration can opt for this stream to gain additional knowledge and practical experience. Upon successful completion, students can pursue the Payroll Compliance Practitioner (PCP) designation through The National Payroll Institute (NPI). The following semester courses are required:
- BUS 1084: Payroll Compliance Legislation (Minimum grade: 65%)
- BUS 1085: Payroll Fundamentals 1 (Minimum grade: 65%)
- ACCT 1036: Principle of Accounting (No pre-requisite)
- BUS 1086: Payroll Fundamentals 2 (Minimum grade: 65%)

Students can also choose Business Electives from the following courses for their Business Administration degree:
- BUS 1044: Business Law (No pre-requisite)
- COMP 1113: Principles of E-Business
- COMP 1010: Business Computer Applications I & II
- CMMK 1127: The Business Media in Canada
- COMM 1034: HRM 2028: Training Design & Delivery or Payroll Compliance Legislation
- BUS 1084: Payroll Compliance Legislation
- BUS 1085: Payroll Fundamentals 1
- BUS 1041: Small Business Management

Context:
Program Offered: Human Resources Management
Courses:
- Payroll Fundamentals 1 (BUS 1084)
- Payroll Fundamentals 2 (BUS 1085)
- Small Business Management (BUS 1084)
- Business Research & Report Writing (COMM 1034)
- Negotiation Skills (MARK 2053)
- HRM 2030: Field Based Advanced Coaching
- HRM 2027: by interview only
- Operations Management (MGMT 4009)
- MATH 1008
- Applied Business Planning (BUS 3015)
- ACCT 2031, MARK 1020, MATH 1008 & HRM 1030
- MGMT 2026: The Successful Project Manager
- BUS 1040
- BUS 1067: Field Education
- Payroll Fundamentals 2 (BUS 1086)
- ECON 1031: Microeconomics
- ECON 1032: Macroeconomics
Program Learning Outcomes:
- Contribute to the planning and implementation of employee recruitment, selection and retention strategies.
- Administer and facilitate the performance management program.
- Coordinate and support the development, implementation and evaluation of employee orientation, training and development programs.
- Implement and support effective employee and labour relations strategies in both non-union and union environments.
- Administer and communicate the organization’s total compensation plan.
- Collaborate with others in the implementation and monitoring of organizational health and safety policies and practices.
- Contribute to the identification of information needs and apply current and emerging information technologies to support the human resources function.
- Contribute to organizational development strategies aimed at promoting organizational effectiveness.
- Present and evaluate communication messages and processes related to the human resources function of the organization.
- Develop, implement and evaluate personal professional development plans to achieve ongoing competence in human resources professional practice.
- Identify and communicate the human resources component of the organization’s business plan.
- Contribute to the collection, analysis and utilization of human resources data.
Tuition & Fees:
- Domestic Tuition: $3,840.00 *
- International Tuition: $17,966.00 **
Additional Costs: Amounts listed are the total of tuition, materials, student service and ancillary fees for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2023. Fees are subject to change for programs starting in Fall 2024 and at later dates. This fee does not include books, which are to be purchased by the student.
* The text mentions "Fall 2023" but it does not specify if the tuition fees apply only to that year or if they are current fees. Therefore, I cannot confirm if $3,840 is the current domestic tuition fee or not.
** Same as above for international tuition fee.

Context:
* The tuition fees for programs starting in Fall 2024 are estimated and subject to board approval.
* Material, student service, and ancillary fees for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2024 are estimated based on prior years and subject to change without notice.
* International students should refer to the International Fees and Related Costs page for more information.
* The program is approved for OSAP funding for applicants who meet OSAP eligibility criteria.
* Applicants need an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, including grade 12 English (C or U) and grade 11 Math (C, M or U) or grade 12 (C or U). Mature students may take the Admissions Assessment for English and Math or consider upgrading to achieve the required credits.
* Applicants who do not meet the minimum admission requirements may still be considered but may need higher grades than stated.
* Course exemptions are available based on college and university credits, more information can be found in the transfer guide.
* English proficiency is necessary for success in the program, review the English proficiency requirements.
* International students should refer to the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements.
* Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges and international students through the George Brown College Online Application System.
* For any queries, contact the college using the Contact Us page.
* The information on the website is subject to change without notice and should not be considered as a representation or warranty. Students are responsible for verifying George Brown College fee requirements and admission requirements.

Context:
International students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System. On-campus information sessions are held regularly for those interested in attending, where questions can be answered, program content and career options discussed, and professors and staff met. Domestic student admission requirements, deadlines, and process inquiries should be directed to the Admissions Office at admissions@georgebrown.ca or the Admissions section. For international students, contact an international recruitment representative specializing by country of origin for virtual meetings or submitting inquiries on the International Contact Us page. For financial aid inquiries, contact the Financial Aid Office at FinAid@georgebrown.ca or visit the Financial Aid section. To speak with an Entry Advisor about various program options, make an appointment and review frequently asked questions. The Centre for Business can be contacted via email at business@georgebrown.ca or phone (416) 415-5000 ext. 2160. Inquiries related to the Business Administration: Human Resources program should contact Viji Vibhu Prakash, Program Co-ordinator and Professor, at Viji.VibhuPrakash@georgebrown.ca.

Programs offered out of the School of Human Resources take place mainly at the St. James Campus, with classes held at 200 King St. E., and 290 Adelaide St. E., Toronto, Ontario, Canada.
